The financial regulator has been accused of caving in to the banks after it shocked the City by dropping a “guilty until proven innocent” rule to hold senior staff to account. 
Andrew Bailey, chief executive of the Prudential Regulation Authority, conceded that he had been warned by lawyers that the key element of the new rules could breach human rights laws. “I didn’t want the regime to have a flaw in it and I’m concerned there would have been a flaw in it,” he told the Treasury select committee yesterday.
